title: Turks in Germany
text:
Turks in Germany, also referred to as German Turks and Turkish Germans (; ), are ethnic <a href="Turkish%20people">Turkish people</a> living in <a href="Germany">Germany</a>. These terms are also used to refer to German-born individuals who are of full or partial Turkish ancestry. Whilst the majority of Turks arrived or originate from <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a>, there are also significant ethnic <a href="Turkish%20minorities">Turkish communities</a> living in <a href="Germany">Germany</a> who come from (or descend from) <a href="Southeastern%20Europe">Southeastern Europe</a> (i.e. <a href="Balkan%20Turks">Balkan Turks</a> from <a href="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>, <a href="Greece">Greece</a>, <a href="North%20Macedonia">North Macedonia</a>, <a href="Serbia">Serbia</a> and <a href="Romania">Romania</a>), the <a href="island%20of%20Cyprus">island of Cyprus</a> (i.e. <a href="Turkish%20Cypriots">Turkish Cypriots</a> from both the <a href="Republic%20of%20Cyprus">Republic of Cyprus</a> and <a href="Northern%20Cyprus">Northern Cyprus</a>), as well as Turkish communities from other parts of the <a href="Levant">Levant</a> (including <a href="Iraq">Iraq</a>, <a href="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>, and <a href="Syria">Syria</a>). At present, ethnic Turkish people form the largest <a href="Ethnic%20groups%20in%20Germany">ethnic minority</a> in Germany. They also form the largest <a href="Turkish%20population">Turkish population</a> in the <a href="Turkish%20diaspora">Turkish diaspora</a>.
Turks who immigrated to Germany brought cultural elements with them, including the <a href="Turkish%20language">Turkish language</a> and <a href="Islam">Islam</a>. These cultural values are often passed down to their children and descendants, but Turkish Germans are also increasingly secular. Greater German society has also been exposed to Turkish culture, particularly in regards to <a href="Turkish%20food">Turkish food</a> and the arts. These changes in Germany, as well as the recently introduced <a href="Germany%20nationality%20law">Germany nationality law</a>s in 1990 and 1999, show that Turkish immigrants and second-, third-, and fourth-generation Turks are no longer merely seen as "foreigners" () in Germany but rather members of German society who are increasingly making their voices heard, whether it be in local and national politics, civic actions, religious organisations, or in cinema, literature, music, and sports.
History.
Turkish migration from the Seljuk Empire and the Rum Seljuk Sultanate.
During a series of invading <a href="Crusades">Crusades</a> by European-Christian armies into lands ruled by Turkic rulers in the <a href="Middle%20East">Middle East</a>, namely under the <a href="Seljuk%20Turks">Seljuk Turks</a> in the <a href="Seljuk%20Empire">Seljuk Empire</a> and the <a href="Sultanate%20of%20Rum">Rum Seljuk Sultanate</a> (but also the <a href="Bahri%20dynasty">Bahri Mamluk Sultanate</a>), many crusaders brought back Turkish male and female prisoners of war to Europe; women were generally baptised and then married whilst "every returning baron and count had [male] prisoners of war in his entourage." Some of the ('booty Turks') taken to Germany during the Crusades also included children and young adults.
The earliest "documented" Turk in Germany is believed to be (Mehmet Sadık Selim Sultan) (ca.1270-1328) from the <a href="Anatolia">Anatolia</a>n Seljuk lands. According to , Soltan was a Turkish officer who was captured by Count von Lechtomir (Reinhart von Württemberg) during his return to Germany from the <a href="Holy%20Land">Holy Land</a> in 1291. By 1304 Soltan married Rebekka Dohlerin; he was baptised the following year as "Johann Soldan", but "out of special love to him", the Count "gave him a Turkish nobility coat of arms". Soldan and his wife had at least three sons, including Eberhardus, Christanianus and Melchior. Another source specifies that Soltan came with Count Reinhart von Württemberg to the residential town of <a href="Brackenheim">Brackenheim</a> in 1304 and was then baptised in 1305 at S. Johannis Church as "Johannes Soldan". There is also evidence that Soltan had a total of 12 sons born in 20 years with Anna Delcherin and Rebecca Bergmännin; eight of his sons passed to the <a href="clergy">clergy</a> and do not appear in genealogy records due to compulsory celibacy associated with the clergy.
Soltan/Soldan's descendants, who were more widespread in south-west Germany, include notable German artists, scholars, doctors, lawyers and politicians. For example, through his maternal grandmother, the renowned German poet and writer <a href="Johann%20Wolfgang%20von%20Goethe">Johann Wolfgang von Goethe</a> belonged to the descendants of the Soldan family and thus had Turkish ancestry. has said that "the German poet prince [i.e. Goethe] with oriental ancestors is by no means a rare exception." Indeed, other descendants of the first recorded Turk in Germany include the lawyer ; the city architects and wine masters <a href="Heinrich%20Soldan">Heinrich Soldan</a> and his son <a href="Johann%20Soldan">Johann Soldan</a> who both served as Mayor of <a href="Frankenberg%2C%20Hesse">Frankenberg</a>; the sculptor and artist ; and the pharmacist Carl Soldan who founded the confectionery company "". Carl Soldan's grandson, Pery Soldan, has said that the family continue to use the crescent and star on their coat of arms. According to Latif Çelik, as of 2008, the Soldan family numbered 2,500 and are also found in Austria, Finland, France and Switzerland.
Turkish migration from the Ottoman Empire.
The <a href="Turkish%20people">Turkish people</a> had greater contact with the <a href="List%20of%20states%20in%20the%20Holy%20Roman%20Empire">German states</a> by the sixteenth century when the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> attempted to expand their territories beyond the north Balkan territories. The Ottoman Turks held two sieges in <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a>: the first <a href="Siege%20of%20Vienna%20%281529%29">Siege of Vienna</a> in 1529 and the <a href="Second%20Siege%20of%20Vienna">Second Siege of Vienna</a> in 1683. The aftermath of the second siege provided the circumstances for a Turkish community to permanently settle in Germany.
Many Ottoman soldiers and camp followers who were left behind after the second siege of Vienna became stragglers or prisoners. It is estimated that at least 500 Turkish prisoners were forcibly settled in Germany. Historical records show that some Turks became traders or took up other professions, particularly in southern Germany. Some Turks fared very well in Germany; for example, one Ottoman Turk is recorded to have been raised to the <a href="House%20of%20Hanover">Hanoverian</a> nobility. Historical records also show that many Ottoman Turks converted to <a href="Christianity">Christianity</a> and became priests or pastors.
The aftermath of the second siege of Vienna led to a series of wars between the Ottoman Empire and the <a href="Holy%20League%20%281684%29">Holy League</a>, known as the "<a href="Great%20Turkish%20War">Great Turkish War</a>", or the "War of the Holy League", which led to a series of Ottoman defeats. Consequently, more Turks were taken by the Europeans as prisoners. The Turkish captives taken to Germany were not solely made up of men. For example, General <a href="Hans%20Adam%20von%20Sch%C3%B6ning">Schöning</a> took "two of the most beautiful women in the world" in <a href="Buda">Buda</a> who later converted to Christianity. Another Turkish captive named Fatima became the mistress of <a href="Augustus%20II%20the%20Strong">Augustus II the Strong</a>, <a href="Elector%20of%20Saxony">Elector of Saxony</a> of the Albertine line of the <a href="House%20of%20Wettin">House of Wettin</a>. Fatima and Augustus had two children: their son, <a href="Frederick%20Augustus%20Rutowsky">Frederick Augustus Rutowsky</a>, became the commander of the <a href="Royal%20Saxon%20Army">Saxon army</a> in 1754-63 whilst their daughter, <a href="Maria%20Anna%20Katharina%20Rutowska">Maria Anna Katharina Rutowska</a>, married into Polish nobility. Records show that at this point it was not uncommon for Turks in Germany to convert to Christianity. For example, records show that 28 Turks converted to Christianity and were settled in <a href="W%C3%BCrttemberg">Württemberg</a>.
With the establishment of the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Prussia">Kingdom of Prussia</a> in 1701, Turkish people continued to enter the German lands as soldiers employed by the Prussian kings. Historical records show that this was particularly evident with the expansion of <a href="Prussia">Prussia</a> in the mid-18th century. For example, in 1731, the <a href="Duke%20of%20Kurland">Duke of Kurland</a> presented twenty Turkish guardsmen to King <a href="Frederick%20William%20I%20of%20Prussia">Frederick William I</a>, and at one time, about 1,000 Muslim soldiers are said to have served in the <a href="Prussian%20Army">Prussian cavalry</a>. The Prussian king's fascination with the <a href="Age%20of%20Enlightenment">Enlightenment</a> was reflected in their consideration for the religious concerns of their Muslim troops. By 1740 <a href="Frederick%20the%20Great">Frederick the Great</a> stated that:
By 1763, an Ottoman legation existed at the Prussian court in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a>. Its third envoy, <a href="Ali%20Aziz%20Efendi">Ali Aziz Efendi</a>, died in 1798 which led to the establishment of the first Muslim cemetery in Germany. However, several decades later, there was a need for another cemetery, as well as a mosque, and the Ottoman sultan <a href="Abd%C3%BClaziz%20I">Abdülaziz I</a> was given permission to patronize a mosque in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a> in 1866.
Once trading treaties were established between the Ottomans and the Prussians in the nineteenth century, Turks and Germans were encouraged to cross over to each other's lands for trade. Consequently, the Turkish community in Germany, and particularly in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a>, grew significantly (as did a German community in <a href="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>) in the years before the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>. These contacts influenced the building of various Turkish-style structures in Germany, such as the <a href="Yenidze">Yenidze</a> cigarette factory in <a href="Dresden">Dresden</a> and the pumping-station in <a href="Potsdam">Potsdam</a>.
During this time, there were also marriages between Germans and Turks. For example, <a href="Karl%20Boy-Ed">Karl Boy-Ed</a>, who was the naval attaché to the German embassy in Washington during <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, was born into a German-Turkish family.
Turkish migration from the Republic of Turkey.
In the mid-twentieth century, <a href="West%20Germany">West Germany</a> experienced the "<a href="Wirtschaftswunder">Wirtschaftswunder</a>" ('economic miracle'); however, the construction of the <a href="Berlin%20Wall">Berlin Wall</a> in 1961 exacerbated West Germany's labour crisis by restricting the flow of immigrants from <a href="East%20Germany">East Germany</a>. Consequently, in the same year, the West German government signed a labour recruitment agreement with the <a href="Republic%20of%20Turkey">Republic of Turkey</a> on 30 October 1961, and officially invited the Turkish people to emigrate to the country. By 1961–1962, German employers played a crucial role in pressuring the State to end the two-year limitation clause of the "<a href="Gastarbeiter">Gastarbeiter</a>" ('guest worker') agreement so that Turkish workers could stay in West Germany for longer.
Most Turkish people who immigrated to West Germany intended to live there temporarily and then return to Turkey so that they could build a new life with the money they had earned. Indeed, return-migration had increased during the <a href="recession">recession</a> of 1966–1967, the <a href="1973%20oil%20crisis">1973 oil crisis</a>, followed by the policy of giving remigration bonuses in the early 1980s. However, the number of Turkish migrants who returned to Turkey ultimately remained relatively small compared to the number of Turkish immigrants arriving in Germany. This was partly due to the <a href="family%20reunification">family reunification</a> rights that were introduced in 1974 which allowed Turkish workers to bring their families to Germany. Consequently, between 1974–88 the number of Turks in Germany nearly doubled, acquiring a normalised <a href="human%20sex%20ratio">sex ratio</a> and a much younger age profile than the German population. Once the recruitment of foreigner workers was reintroduced after the recession of 1967, the BfA () granted most work visas to women. This was in part because labour shortages continued in low paying, low-status service jobs such as electronics, textiles, and garment work; and in part to further the goal of family reunification.
The <a href="fall%20of%20the%20Berlin%20Wall">fall of the Berlin Wall</a> in 1989, and the reunification of <a href="East%20Germany">East</a> and <a href="West%20Germany">West Germany</a>, was followed by intense public debate around the articulations of national identity and citizenship, including the place of Germany's Turkish minority in the future of a united Germany. These debates about citizenship were accompanied by expressions of <a href="xenophobia">xenophobia</a> and ethnic violence that targeted the <a href="Turkish%20population">Turkish population</a>. Anti-immigrant sentiment was especially strong in the former eastern states of Germany, which underwent profound social and economic transformations during the reunification process. Turkish communities experienced considerable fear for their safety throughout Germany, with some 1,500 reported cases of right wing violence, and 2,200 cases the year after. The political rhetoric calling for foreigner-free zones () and the rise of <a href="neo-Nazi">neo-Nazi</a> groups sharpened public awareness of integration issues and generated intensified support among liberal Germans for the competing idea of Germany as a "<a href="multicultural">multicultural</a>" society. Citizenship laws that established eligibility according to place of birth rather than according to descent have been slow in coming and restrictions on dual citizenship are still onerous. However, increasing numbers of second-generation Turkish-Germans have opted for <a href="German%20citizenship">German citizenship</a> and are becoming more involved in the political process.
Turkish migration from the Balkans.
Bulgaria.
Initially, <a href="Bulgarian%20Turks">Turkish Bulgarians</a> arrived in Germany during the introduction of the <a href="family%20reunification">family reunification</a> laws of 1974; they were able to take advantage of this law despite the very small number of Bulgarian citizens in Germany because some Turkish workers in Germany who arrived from Turkey were actually part of the Turkish minority who had left Bulgaria during the communist regime in the 1980s and still held <a href="Bulgarian%20citizenship">Bulgarian citizenship</a>, alongside their <a href="Turkish%20citizenship">Turkish citizenship</a>.
The migration of Turkish Bulgarians to Germany increased further once communism in <a href="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a> ended in 1989. In particular, Turkish Bulgarians who did not join the massive migration wave to Turkey during the so-called "<a href="Revival%20Process">Revival Process</a>" were faced with severe economic disadvantages and continued to face discrimination through state policies of <a href="Bulgarisation">Bulgarisation</a>. Hence, from the early 1990s onwards many Bulgarian Turks sought asylum in Germany.
The number of Turkish Bulgarians in Germany has significantly increased since Bulgaria was admitted into the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a>, which has allowed many Bulgarian Turks to use the <a href="freedom%20of%20movement">freedom of movement</a> to enter Germany. The Bulgarian Turks have generally been attracted to Germany because they rely on the well-established Turkish-German community for gaining employment.
Thus, the social network of the first waves of political emigration, as well as the preservation of kinship, has opened an opportunity for many Turkish Bulgarian to continue to migrate to Western Europe, with the majority continuing to arrive in Germany. As a result, Turkish Bulgarians in Germany outnumber the large Turkish Bulgarian diasporas in countries such as the <a href="Netherlands">Netherlands</a> where they make up about 80% of Bulgarian citizens. 
Greece.
From the 1950s onwards, the <a href="Turks%20in%20Greece">Turkish minority</a> of <a href="Greece">Greece</a>, particularly the <a href="Turks%20of%20Western%20Thrace">Turks of Western Thrace</a>, began to immigrate to <a href="Germany">Germany</a> alongside other <a href="Greek%20citizens">Greek citizens</a>. Whilst many Western Thrace Turks had intended to return to Greece after working for a number of years, a new Greek law was introduced which effectively forced the minority to remain in Germany. Article 19 of the 1955 <a href="Greek%20Constitution">Greek Constitution</a> essentially stripped the <a href="Western%20Thrace%20Turks">Western Thrace Turks</a> living abroad (particularly those in <a href="Germany">Germany</a> and <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a>) of their <a href="Greek%20citizenship">Greek citizenship</a>. According to Article 19 of the Greek Constitution 
This law continued to affect Western Thrace Turks studying in Germany in the late 1980s, who intended to return to Greece. A report published by the <a href="Human%20Rights%20Watch">Human Rights Watch</a> in 1990 confirmed that:
Despite many being stripped of their Greek citizenship since 1955, migration of Western Thrace Turks to Germany has continued to increase significantly. Firstly, in the 1960s and 1970s many came to Germany because the Thracian tobacco industry was affected by a severe crisis and many tobacco growers lost their income. Between 1970 and 2010, approximately 40,000 Western Thrace Turks arrived in Western Europe, most of which settled in Germany. In addition, between 2010 and 2018, a further 30,000 Western Thrace Turks left for Western Europe due to the <a href="Greek%20government-debt%20crisis">Greek government-debt crisis</a>. Of these 70,000 immigrants (which excludes the numbers which arrived before 1970), around 80% live in Germany.
In 2013 <a href="Cemile%20Giousouf">Cemile Giousouf</a> became the first Western Thrace Turk to become a member of the German parliament. She was the first <a href="Muslim">Muslim</a> to be elected for the <a href="Christian%20Democratic%20Union%20of%20Germany">Christian Democratic Union of Germany</a>.
North Macedonia.
There has been migration from the <a href="Turks%20in%20North%20Macedonia">Turkish Macedonian</a> minority group which have come to Germany alongside other citizens of <a href="North%20Macedonia">North Macedonia</a>, including <a href="Macedonians%20%28ethnic%20group%29">ethnic Macedonians</a> and <a href="Albanian%20Macedonians">Albanian Macedonians</a>.
In 2021, Furkan Çako, who is a former Macedonian minister and member of the Security Council, urged Turkish Macedonians living in Germany to participate in North Macedonia's 2021 census.
Romania.
Between 2002 and 2011 there was a significant decrease in the population of the <a href="Turks%20of%20Romania">Turkish Romanian</a> minority group due to the admission of <a href="Romania">Romania</a> into the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a> and the subsequent relaxation of the travelling and migration regulations. Hence, Turkish Romanians, especially from the <a href="Dobruja">Dobruja</a> region, have joined other Romanian citizens (e.g. ethnic <a href="Romanians">Romanians</a>, <a href="Tatars%20of%20Romania">Tatars</a>, etc.) in migrating mostly to Germany, Austria, Italy, Spain and the UK.
Turkish migration from the Levant.
Cyprus.
<a href="Turkish%20Cypriots">Turkish Cypriots</a> migrants began to leave the island of <a href="Cyprus">Cyprus</a> for Western Europe due to economic and political reasons in the 20th century, especially after the <a href="Cyprus%20crisis%20of%201963%E2%80%9364">Cyprus crisis of 1963–64</a> and then the <a href="1974%20Cypriot%20coup%20d%27%C3%A9tat">1974 Cypriot coup d'état</a> carried out by the <a href="Greek%20military%20junta%20of%201967%E2%80%931974">Greek military junta</a> which was followed by the reactionary <a href="Turkish%20invasion%20of%20Cyprus">Turkish invasion</a> of the island. More recently, with the <a href="2004%20enlargement%20of%20the%20European%20Union">2004 enlargement of the European Union</a>, Turkish Cypriots who hold <a href="Cypriot%20citizenship">Cypriot citizenship</a> have had the <a href="Freedom%20of%20movement%20for%20workers%20in%20the%20European%20Union">right</a> to live and work across the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a>, including in Germany, as <a href="Citizenship%20of%20the%20European%20Union">EU citizens</a>. As of 2016, there are approximately 2,000 Turkish Cypriots in Germany, which is the second largest <a href="Turkish%20Cypriot%20diaspora">Turkish Cypriot diaspora</a> in Western Europe (after the <a href="UK">UK</a>).
The <a href="Northern%20Cyprus">TRNC</a> provides assistance to its Turkish Cypriots residents living in Germany via the TRNC Berlin Honorary Representative Office; the TRNC Köln Honorary Representative Office; the TRNC Bavarian Honorary Attaché; and the TRNC Bavarian Honorary Representative Office. These <a href="List%20of%20diplomatic%20missions%20of%20Northern%20Cyprus">Representative Offices and Honorary Representatives</a> also promote friendly relations between Northern Cyprus and Germany, as well as economic and cultural relations.
Lebanon.
Due to the numerous <a href="Lebanese%20Civil%20War">war</a>s in <a href="Lebanon">Lebanon</a> since the 1970s onwards, many <a href="Turks%20in%20Lebanon">Turkish Lebanese people</a> have sought <a href="Safety">refuge</a> in <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a> and <a href="Europe">Europe</a>, particularly in <a href="Germany">Germany</a>. Indeed, many Lebanese Turks were aware of the large Turkish-German population and saw this as an opportunity to find work once settling in Europe. In particular, the largest wave of Turkish Lebanese migration occurred once the <a href="2006%20Lebanon%20War">Israel-Lebanon war of 2006</a> began. During this period more than 20,000 Turks fled Lebanon, particularly from <a href="Beirut">Beirut</a>, and settled in European countries, including Germany.
Iraq.
In 2008 there were 85,000 <a href="Iraq">Iraq</a>is living in Germany, of which approximately 7,000 were from the <a href="Iraqi%20Turkmen">Turkish Iraqi minority group</a>; hence, the Iraqi Turks formed around 8.5% of the total number of <a href="Iraqis%20in%20Germany">Iraqi citizens living in Germany</a>. The majority of Iraqi Turks live in <a href="Munich">Munich</a>.
Syria.
Established in Germany, the , or STKYDA, ('Syrian Turkmen Culture and Solidarity Association – Europe') was the first <a href="Syrian%20Turkmen">Syrian Turkmen</a> association to be launched in Europe. It was established in order to help the growing Syrian Turkmen community which arrived in the country since the <a href="European%20migrant%20crisis">European migrant crisis</a> which started in 2014 and saw its peak in 2015. The association includes Syrian Turkmen youth activists originating from all Syrian cities and who are now living across Western European cities.
Demographics.
Population.
German state data and estimates.
The German state does not allow citizens to self-declare their identity; consequently, the statistics published in the official German census does not show data on ethnicity. According to the 2011 census, 2.7 million German residents had a "migration background" from Turkey. However, this excludes ethnic Turks with both parents who were born with German citizenship as well as the significant <a href="Turkish%20minorities">ethnic Turkish communities</a> which have migrated to Germany from the <a href="Balkans">Balkans</a> and the <a href="Levant">Levant</a>. As early as 1997 (i.e. 14 years before the 2011 census), the <a href="Chancellor%20of%20Germany">Chancellor of Germany</a>, <a href="Helmut%20Kohl">Helmut Kohl</a>, said that there was already 3 million Turks living in Germany. Moreover, at the time of the 2011 census, a report published by the <a href="Embassy%20of%20Germany%2C%20Washington%2C%20D.C.">Embassy of Germany, Washington, D.C.</a> said that there were roughly 4 million Turks in Germany, of which 2 million had German citizenship. More recently, in 2013, the German chancellor, <a href="Angela%20Merkel">Angela Merkel</a>, said that "Germany's "<a href="Leitkultur">Leitkultur</a>" needs to be accepted by Germany's seven million Turkish immigrants".
Academic estimates.
Throughout the decades estimates by academics of the Turkish-German population have varied. In 1990, David Scott Bell et al. put it at between 2.5 million and 3 million Turks in Germany. A lower 1993 estimate by et al. said there were 1.8 million Turks. However, in 1994 <a href="John%20Milton%20Yinger">John Milton Yinger</a> pointed out that the German Government's Special Commission on Integration, , observed that there were "more than" 3 million Turks, including third-generation descendants, and that 79,000 new babies were born each year within the community. The estimate of three million was also given by other scholars in the mid-1990s. A higher estimate of 4 million Turks (including three generations) was reported by <a href="John%20Pilger">John Pilger</a> in 1993 and the in 1994. Moreover, Marilya Veteto-Conrad said that in the German capital there was already "over a million Turks in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a> alone" in 1996. 
In 2003, Ina Kötter et al. said that there was ""more than" 4 million people of Turkish origin" in Germany; this has also been reiterated by other scholars. However, <a href="Michael%20Murphy%20Andregg">Michael Murphy Andregg</a> said that by the 2000s "Germany was home to "at least" five million Turks"; various scholars have also given this estimate. <a href="Jytte%20Klausen">Jytte Klausen</a> cited German statistics in 2005 showing 2.4 million Turks, but acknowledged that unlike Catholics, Protestants, and Jews, the Turkish community cannot allocate their ethnic or religious identity in official counts. Indeed, a 2007 study by <a href="Clifford%20Geertz">Clifford Geertz</a> claimed that there was already "two million Turks in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a>" alone. <a href="Daniel%20Goldhagen">Daniel Goldhagen</a> placed the total Turkish population in Germany at 6 million in 2013. A higher estimate of 7 million Turks was given by <a href="Paul%20Gottfried">Paul Gottfried</a> in 2003, and <a href="Tessa%20Szyszkowitz">Tessa Szyszkowitz</a> quoted a senior European official who also said there was seven million Turks living in Germany in 2005. 
As of 2020, numerous scholars have estimated that there are approximately 7 million Turks in Germany, including <a href="Graham%20E.%20Fuller">Graham E. Fuller</a>, James G. Lacey, Daniela Coli, and George K. Zestos and Rachel N. Cooke. Non-academic reports published by "<a href="The%20Times">The Times</a>", the "<a href="Foundation%20for%20Subsidiarity">Foundation for Subsidiarity</a>", and "<a href="Marianne%20%28magazine%29">Marianne</a>" have also suggested this figure.
Settlements.
The Turkish community in Germany is concentrated predominantly in <a href="Urban%20area">urban</a> centers. The vast majority are found in the former <a href="West%20Germany">West Germany</a>, particularly in industrial regions such as the states of <a href="North%20Rhine-Westphalia">North Rhine-Westphalia</a> (where a third of Turkish Germans live), and <a href="Baden-W%C3%BCrttemberg">Baden-Württemberg</a> and the working-class neighbourhoods of cities like <a href="Turks%20in%20Berlin">Berlin</a> (especially in <a href="Neuk%C3%B6lln%20%28locality%29">Neukölln</a>), <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>, <a href="Bremen">Bremen</a>, <a href="Cologne">Cologne</a>, <a href="Duisburg">Duisburg</a>, <a href="D%C3%BCsseldorf">Düsseldorf</a>, <a href="Frankfurt">Frankfurt</a>, <a href="Mannheim">Mannheim</a>, <a href="Mainz">Mainz</a>, <a href="Nuremberg">Nuremberg</a>, <a href="Munich">Munich</a>, and <a href="Stuttgart">Stuttgart</a>. Among the German districts in 2011, <a href="Duisburg">Duisburg</a>, <a href="Gelsenkirchen">Gelsenkirchen</a>, <a href="Heilbronn">Heilbronn</a>, <a href="Herne%2C%20North%20Rhine-Westphalia">Herne</a> and <a href="Ludwigshafen">Ludwigshafen</a> had the highest shares of migrants from Turkey according to census data.
Return migration.
In regards to return-migration, many Turkish nationals and Turkish Germans have also migrated from <a href="Germany">Germany</a> to <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a>, for retirement or professional reasons. Official German records show that there are 2.8 million "returnees"; however, the German Embassy in <a href="Ankara">Ankara</a> estimates the true number to be four million, acknowledging the differences in German official data and the realities of the under-reporting by migrants.
Integration.
Turkish immigrants make up Germany's largest immigrant group and have been ranked last in Berlin Institute's integration ranking.
During a speech in <a href="D%C3%BCsseldorf">Düsseldorf</a> in 2011, Turkish Prime Minister <a href="Recep%20Tayyip%20Erdo%C4%9Fan">Recep Tayyip Erdoğan</a> urged Turks in Germany to <a href="Social%20integration">integrate</a>, but not <a href="Cultural%20assimilation">assimilate</a>, a statement that caused a political outcry in Germany.
Citizenship.
For decades Turkish citizens in Germany were unable to become <a href="German%20nationality%20law">German citizens</a> because of the traditional German construct of "nationhood". The legal notion of citizenship was based on "blood ties" of a German parent ("<a href="jus%20sanguinis">jus sanguinis</a>") – as opposed to citizenship based on country of birth and residence ("<a href="jus%20soli">jus soli</a>"). This adhered to the political notion that Germany was not a country of immigration. For this reason, only those who were of partial Turkish origin (and had one parent who was "ethnically" <a href="German%20people">German</a>) could obtain German citizenship.
In 1990 Germany's citizenship law was somewhat relaxed with the introduction of the Foreigner's Law; this gave Turkish workers the right to apply for a permanent residency permit after eight years of living in the country. In regards to people of Turkish origin born in Germany, who were also legally "foreign", they were given the right to acquire German citizenship at the age of eighteen, provided that they gave up their Turkish citizenship. Hence, they were deprived of the right to hold <a href="dual%20citizenship">dual citizenship</a> because it would increase the <a href="Turkish%20population">Turkish population</a> in the country. Chancellor <a href="Helmut%20Kohl">Helmut Kohl</a> officially stated this as the main reason for denying dual citizenship in 1997 when he said the following:
Nonetheless, another citizenship reform law was soon introduced after Helmut Kohl finished his last term as Chancellor. The Citizenship Law of 1999, which was officially taken into effect on 1 January 2000, has facilitated the acquisition of German citizenship for people born outside of Germany, making it available to Turkish immigrants after eight years of legal residence in the country. The law's most innovative provision granted <a href="dual%20citizenship">dual citizenship</a> to Turkish-origin children born in Germany; however, this right to dual citizenship ends at age 23 and the bearers must decide whether to keep their German citizenship or the citizenship of their parent's country of birth.
Former Turkish citizens who have given up their citizenship can apply for the 'Blue Card' (), which gives them some rights in Turkey, such as the right to live and work in Turkey, the right to possess and inherit land or the right to inherit; however, they do not have the right to vote. 
In 2011 the <a href="Embassy%20of%20Germany%2C%20Washington%2C%20D.C.">Embassy of Germany, Washington, D.C.</a> reported that as of 2005 there were 2 million Turks who already had German citizenship.
Culture.
The Turkish people who immigrated to Germany brought their culture with them, including their language, religion, food, and arts. These cultural traditions have also been passed down to their descendants who maintain these values. Consequently, Turkish Germans have also exposed their culture to the greater German society. Numerous Turkish restaurants, grocery stores, teahouses, and mosques are scattered across Germany. The Turks in Germany have also been exposed to <a href="German%20culture">German culture</a>, which has influenced the Turkish dialect spoken by the Turkish community in Germany.
Food.
<a href="Turkish%20cuisine">Turkish cuisine</a> first arrived in Germany during the sixteenth century and was consumed among aristocratic circles. However, Turkish food became available to the greater German society from the mid-twentieth century onwards with the arrival of Turkish immigrants. By the early 1970s Turks began to open fast-food restaurants serving popular <a href="kebap">kebap</a> dishes. Today there are Turkish restaurants scattered throughout the country selling popular dishes like <a href="d%C3%B6ner%20kebap">döner kebap</a> in take-away stalls to more authentic domestic foods in family-run restaurants. Since the 1970s, Turks have opened grocery stores and open-air markets where they sell ingredients suitable for Turkish home-cooking, such as spices, fruits, and vegetables.
Language.
<a href="Turkish%20language">Turkish</a> is the second most spoken language in Germany, after <a href="German%20language">German</a>. It was brought to the country by Turkish immigrants who spoke it as their first language. These immigrants mainly learned German through employment, mass media, and social settings, and it has now become a <a href="second%20language">second language</a> for many of them. Nonetheless, most Turkish immigrants have passed down their <a href="mother%20tongue">mother tongue</a> to their children and descendants. In general, Turkish Germans become <a href="bilingual">bilingual</a> at an early age, learning Turkish at home and German in state schools; thereafter, a dialectal variety often remains in their repertoire of both languages.
Turkish Germans mainly speak the German language more fluently than their "domestic"-style Turkish language. Consequently, they often speak the Turkish language with a <a href="German%20accent">German accent</a> or a modelled <a href="German%20dialect">German dialect</a>. It is also common within the community to modify the Turkish language by adding German grammatical and syntactical structures. Parents generally encourage their children to improve their Turkish language skills further by attending private Turkish classes or choosing Turkish as a subject at school. In some states of Germany the Turkish language has even been approved as a subject to be studied for the "<a href="Abitur">Abitur</a>".
Turkish has also been influential in greater German society. For example, advertisements and banners in public spaces can be found written in Turkish. Hence, it is also familiar to other ethnic groups – it can even serve as a vernacular for some non-Turkish children and adolescents in urban neighborhoods with dominant Turkish communities.
It is also common within the Turkish community to <a href="code-switch">code-switch</a> between the German and Turkish languages. By the early 1990s a new <a href="sociolect">sociolect</a> called <a href="Kanak%20Sprak">Kanak Sprak</a> or was coined by the Turkish-German author <a href="Feridun%20Zaimo%C4%9Flu">Feridun Zaimoğlu</a> to refer to the German "ghetto" dialect spoken by the Turkish youth. However, with the developing formation of a Turkish middle class in Germany, there is an increasing number of people of Turkish-origin who are proficient in using the standard German language, particularly in academia and the arts.
Religion.
The Turkish people in Germany are predominantly <a href="Muslim">Muslim</a> and form the largest ethnic group which practices <a href="Islam%20in%20Germany">Islam in Germany</a>. Since the 1960s, "Turkish" was seen as synonymous with "<a href="Muslim">Muslim</a>"; this is because <a href="Islam">Islam</a> is considered to have a "Turkish character" in Germany. This Turkish character is particularly evident in the Ottoman/Turkish-style architecture of many mosques scattered across Germany. In 2016, approximately 2,000 of Germany's 3,000 mosques were Turkish, of which 900 were financed by the <a href="Turkish-Islamic%20Union%20for%20Religious%20Affairs">Diyanet İşleri Türk-İslam Birliği</a>, an arm of the Turkish government, and the remainder by other political Turkish groups. There is an ethnic Turkish <a href="Christianity">Christian</a> community in Germany; most of them came from recent Muslim Turkish backgrounds.
Discrimination and anti-Turkism.
Discrimination.
It has been criticized that there is a media and political bias against Turkish Germans compared to Kurds in Germany, for example, when pro-Erdogan Turkish-Germans demonstrate the media and many politicians warn against these demonstrations, but the same media and politicians remain silent about the many regular pro-PKK Kurdish demonstrations.
In 1985 the German journalist <a href="G%C3%BCnter%20Wallraff">Günter Wallraff</a> shocked the German public with his internationally successful book "" ('In the Pits' or 'Way Down') in which he reported the discrimination faced by Turkish people in German society. He disguised himself as a Turkish worker called "Ali Levent" for over two years and took on minimal-wage jobs and confronted German institutions. He found that many employers did not register or insure their Turkish workers. Major employers like <a href="Thyssen%20AG">Thyssen</a> did not give their Turkish workers adequate breaks and did not pay them their full wage.
It has been, and still is, also reported that Turkish-Germans were being discriminated against at school from early age and in workplaces. It has also been found that teachers discriminate against non-German sounding names and tend to give worse grades based on names alone. The studies showed that even though a student might have had the exact number of right and wrong answers, or the exact paper, the teachers favour German names. 
This creates a vicious cycle where teachers favour students of German descent over non-Germans, including Turkish students, which results in worse education. This later results in Turkish people not being able to take what are deemed to be "higher-skill jobs", which nonetheless deepens the cracks in the cycle. 
There are also the reports of discrimination against Turkish-Germans in other areas such as sports, one example being the discrimination against the football player <a href="Mesut%20%C3%96zil">Mesut Özil</a>.
Attacks against the Turkish community in Germany.
The fall of the <a href="Berlin%20wall">Berlin wall</a> in 1989, and the <a href="reunification%20of%20Germany">reunification of Germany</a>, saw a sharp rise in violent attacks against Turkish-Germans. A series of arson attacks, bombings, and shootings have targeted the Turkish community in both public and private spaces, such as in their homes, cultural centres, and businesses. Consequently, many victims have been killed or severely injured by these attacks.
On 27 October 1991, , a 19-year-old student from <a href="Kreuzberg">Kreuzberg</a>, along with his four Turkish friends were involved in a violent confrontation with three German brothers. As a consequence, Ekşi died due to <a href="head%20injuries">head injuries</a> caused with a <a href="baseball%20bat">baseball bat</a> which was wrested by the 25-year-old attacker from Ekşi's friend. His death sparked a massive outrage in the local Turkish community alleging <a href="fascist">fascist</a> motives. This was, however, dismissed by a court as an "overreaction" while acknowledging and condemning open and hidden <a href="xenophobia">xenophobia</a> in Germany. His funeral in November 1991 was attended by 5,000 people. 
A year after Ekşi's murder, on 22 November 1992, two Turkish girls, Ayşe Yılmaz and Yeliz Arslan, and their grandmother, Bahide Arslan, were killed by two <a href="neo-Nazis">neo-Nazis</a> in <a href="1992%20M%C3%B6lln%20arson%20attack">an arson attack in their home in Mölln</a>.
On 9 March 1993, , aged 56, was attacked by two members of the German <a href="anti-immigrant">anti-immigrant</a> <a href="political%20party">political party</a> "<a href="The%20Republicans%20%28Germany%29">The Republicans</a>" whilst waiting at a bus stop in <a href="M%C3%BClheim">Mülheim</a>. The attackers verbally assaulted him prompting a defensive reaction after which one of the attackers threatened him with a gun pointing at his head. Demiral suffered a heart-attack and died at the scene of the crime.
Two months later, on 28 May 1993, <a href="1993%20Solingen%20arson%20attack">four young neo-Nazi German men aged 16–23 set fire to the house of a Turkish family in Solingen</a>. Three girls and two women died and 14 other members of the extended family were severely injured in the attack. German Chancellor <a href="Helmut%20Kohl">Helmut Kohl</a> did not attend the memorial services.
Neo-Nazi attacks continued throughout the 1990s. On 18 February 1994, the Bayram family were attacked on their doorstep by a neo-Nazi neighbour in <a href="Darmstadt">Darmstadt</a>. The attack was not well publicised until one of the victims, <a href="Asl%C4%B1%20Bayram">Aslı Bayram</a>, was crowned <a href="Miss%20Germany">Miss Germany</a> in 2005. The armed neo-Nazi neighbour shot Aslı on her left arm and then the attacker shot Aslı's father, Ali Bayram, who died from the gunshot.
Between 2000 and 2006 several Turkish shopkeepers were attacked in numerous cities in Germany. The attacks were called the "<a href="Bosphorus%20serial%20murders">Bosphorus serial murders</a>" () by the German authorities or <a href="pejoratively">pejoratively</a> "<a href="D%C3%B6ner%20murders">Kebab murders</a>" () by the press – which saw eight Turkish and one <a href="Greeks">Greek</a> person killed. Initially, the German media suspected that Turkish gangs were behind these murders. However, by 2011 it came to light that the perpetrators were in fact the neo-Nazi group the <a href="National%20Socialist%20Underground">National Socialist Underground</a>. This neo-Nazi group was also responsible for the June <a href="2004%20Cologne%20bombing">2004 Cologne bombing</a> which resulted in 22 Turkish people being injured.
On 3 February 2008, nine Turkish people, including five children, died in a blaze in <a href="Ludwigshafen">Ludwigshafen</a> (). While there have been speculations by the Turkish media about the origin of the fire suspecting an <a href="arson%20attack">arson attack</a> and allegations of slow <a href="Emergency%20service%23Response%20time">fire response time</a>, these were rejected by an investigation and the cause of the fire was determined to have been an electrical fault. Nevertheless, many German and Turkish politicians including <a href="Turkish%20prime%20minister">Turkish prime minister</a> <a href="Recep%20Tayyip%20Erdo%C4%9Fan">Recep Tayyip Erdoğan</a> together with locally elected <a href="Member%20of%20parliament">MP</a> of the <a href="German%20parliament">German parliament</a> and appointed Minister of State for Integration in the <a href="German%20Chancellery">Federal Chancellery</a> and German Federal Government Commissioner for Migration, Refugees and Integration <a href="Maria%20B%C3%B6hmer">Maria Böhmer</a> or <a href="Minister%20President">Minister President</a> of <a href="Rhineland-Palatinate">Rhineland-Palatinate</a> <a href="Kurt%20Beck">Kurt Beck</a> visited the site to express their condolences. Chancellor <a href="Angela%20Merkel">Angela Merkel</a> was criticised for not attending a demonstration held in memory of the victims by 16,000 people.
Not all attacks on Turks have been perpetrated by neo-Nazi right-wing Germans: for example, the perpetrator of <a href="2016%20Munich%20shooting">a mass shooting in Munich</a> on 22 July 2016 who deliberately targeted people of Turkish and Arab origin. On that day, he killed nine victims, of which four victims were of Turkish origin: Can Leyla, aged 14, Selçuk Kılıç, aged 17, and Sevda Dağ, aged 45; as well as Hüseyin Dayıcık, aged 19, who was a Greek national of Turkish origin.
On 19 February 2020, a German neo-Nazi who expressed hate for non-German people, <a href="2020%20Hanau%20shootings">carried out two mass shootings</a> in the city of <a href="Hanau">Hanau</a>, killing nine foreigners. He then returned to his home, killed his mother and committed suicide. Five of the nine victims were Turkish citizens.
On 2 April 2020, in <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>, a German family of Turkish descent claimed to have received a threatening letter with xenophobic content allegedly containing <a href="COVID-19">the coronavirus</a>.
Crime.
Turkish gangs.
In 2014, the annual report into organized crime, presented in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a> by interior minister Thomas de Maizière, showed that there were 57 Turkish gangs in Germany. In 2016, the <a href="Die%20Welt">Die Welt</a> and <a href="Bild">Bild</a> reported that new Turkish motorbike gang, the Osmanien Germania is growing rapidly. The <a href="Hannoversche%20Allgemeine%20Zeitung">"Hannoversche Allgemeine"</a> newspaper claimed that the Osmanien Germania is advancing more and more into red-light districts, which increases the likelihood of a bloody territorial battle with established gangs like the <a href="Hells%20Angels">Hells Angels Motorcycle Club</a>.
Turkish ultra-nationalist movements.
As a result of the immigration wave in the 1960s and 1970s, far right and ultranationalist organisations established themselves in Germany such as the <a href="Grey%20Wolves%20%28organization%29">Grey Wolves</a>, , (ATB) and (ATIB), which brought the conflicts from their home country with them with racism towards Kurds and Armenians in Germany. In 2017, ATB and ATIB together had about 303 locations with 18,500 members.
Popular culture.
Media.
Films.
The first phase in <a href="Turkish-German%20Cinema">Turkish-German Cinema</a> began in the 1970s and lasted through to the 1980s; it involved writers placing much of their attention on story-lines that represented the living and working conditions of the Turkish immigrant workers in Germany. By the 1990s a second phase shifted towards focusing more on mass entertainment and involved the work of Turkish and German-born Turkish German filmmakers. Critical engagements in story-telling increased further by the turn of the twenty-first century. Numerous films of the 1990s onwards launched the careers of many film directors, writers, and actors and actresses.
<a href="Fatih%20Akin">Fatih Akin</a>'s films, which often examine the place of the Turkish diaspora in Germany, have won numerous awards and have launched the careers of many of its cast including "<a href="Short%20Sharp%20Shock%20%28film%29">Short Sharp Shock</a>" (1998) starring <a href="Mehmet%20Kurtulu%C5%9F">Mehmet Kurtuluş</a> and <a href="%C4%B0dil%20%C3%9Cner">İdil Üner</a>; "<a href="Head-On%20%28film%29">Head-On</a>" (2004) starring <a href="Birol%20%C3%9Cnel">Birol Ünel</a> and <a href="Sibel%20Kekilli">Sibel Kekilli</a>; "<a href="Kebab%20Connection">Kebab Connection</a>" (2004) starring <a href="Denis%20Moschitto">Denis Moschitto</a>; "<a href="The%20Edge%20of%20Heaven%20%28film%29">The Edge of Heaven</a>" (2007) starring <a href="Baki%20Davrak">Baki Davrak</a>; and "<a href="Soul%20Kitchen%20%28film%29">Soul Kitchen</a>" (2009) starring <a href="Birol%20%C3%9Cnel">Birol Ünel</a>.
Other notable films which have a <a href="Transnational%20cinema">transnational</a> context include <a href="Feridun%20Zaimo%C4%9Flu">Feridun Zaimoğlu</a>'s book-turned-film ' (2000); ' (2004); and <a href="%C3%96zg%C3%BCr%20Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m">Özgür Yıldırım</a>'s "<a href="Chiko">Chiko</a>" (2008). Several Turkish-German comedy films have also intentionally used comical stereotypes to encourage its viewers to question their preconceived ideas of "the Other", such as <a href="Z%C3%BCli%20Alada%C4%9F">Züli Aladağ</a>'s film ' ("300 words of German", 2013), starring <a href="Almila%20Bagriacik">Almila Bagriacik</a>, , <a href="Aykut%20Kayac%C4%B1k">Aykut Kayacık</a>, and <a href="Vedat%20Erincin">Vedat Erincin</a>. Similarly, other recent Turkish-German comedies like ' ("My Crazy Turkish Wedding", 2006), starring <a href="Hilmi%20S%C3%B6zer">Hilmi Sözer</a>, <a href="Ercan%20%C3%96z%C3%A7elik">Ercan Özçelik</a>, <a href="Aykut%20Kayac%C4%B1k">Aykut Kayacık</a>, and <a href="%C3%96zay%20Fecht">Özay Fecht</a>, and the film "" ("Evet, I do!", 2009), starring numerous Turkish-German actors such as <a href="Demir%20G%C3%B6kg%C3%B6l">Demir Gökgöl</a>, <a href="Emine%20Sevgi%20%C3%96zdamar">Emine Sevgi Özdamar</a>, <a href="Erden%20Alkan">Erden Alkan</a>, <a href="Gandi%20Mukli">Gandi Mukli</a>, <a href="H%C3%BClya%20Duyar">Hülya Duyar</a>, <a href="Jale%20Ar%C4%B1kan">Jale Arıkan</a>, <a href="Lilay%20Huser">Lilay Huser</a>, <a href="Meral%20Perin">Meral Perin</a>, <a href="M%C3%BCrt%C3%BCz%20Yolcu">Mürtüz Yolcu</a>, <a href="Sema%20Meray">Sema Meray</a>, and <a href="Sinan%20Akku%C5%9F">Sinan Akkuş</a>, have emphasised how the Turkish and German cultures come together in contemporary German society. By focusing on similarities and differences of the two cultures using comedy, these films have shifted from the earlier Turkish-German drama films of the 1980s which focused on culture clashes; in its place, these films have celebrated integration and interethnic romance.
By 2011 <a href="Yasemin%20%C5%9Eamdereli">Yasemin Şamdereli</a> and <a href="Nesrin%20%C5%9Eamdereli">Nesrin Şamdereli</a>'s comedy film "<a href="Almanya%20%E2%80%93%20Willkommen%20in%20Deutschland">Almanya: Welcome to Germany</a>", starring <a href="Aylin%20Tezel">Aylin Tezel</a> and <a href="Fahri%20Yard%C4%B1m">Fahri Yardım</a>, premiered at the <a href="Berlin%20Film%20Festival">Berlin Film Festival</a> and was attended by the German President and the Turkish Ambassador to celebrate fifty years since the mass migration of Turkish workers to Germany. Indeed, stories confronting Turkish labour migration, and debates about <a href="Social%20integration">integration</a>, <a href="multiculturalism">multiculturalism</a>, and identity, are reoccurring themes in Turkish-German cinema.
Nonetheless, not all films directed, produced or written by Turkish Germans are necessarily about the "Turkish-experience" in Germany. Several Turkish Germans have been involved in other genres, such as <a href="B%C3%BClent%20Akinci">Bülent Akinci</a> who directed the German drama "<a href="Running%20on%20Empty%20%282006%20film%29">Running on Empty</a>" (2006), <a href="Mennan%20Yapo">Mennan Yapo</a> who has directed the American supernatural thriller "<a href="Premonition%20%282007%20film%29">Premonition</a>" (2007), and <a href="Thomas%20Arslan">Thomas Arslan</a> who directed the German Western film "<a href="Gold%20%282013%20film%29">Gold</a>" (2013).
Several Turkish-origin actors from Germany have also starred in Turkish films, such as <a href="Haluk%20Piyes">Haluk Piyes</a> who starred in "<a href="O%20da%20beni%20seviyor">O da beni seviyor</a>" (2001).
Television.
In the first decade of the twenty-first century several German television series in which the experience of Turkish-Germans as a major theme gained popularity in Germany and in some cases gained popularity abroad too. For example, "<a href="Sinan%20Toprak%20ist%20der%20Unbestechliche">Sinan Toprak ist der Unbestechliche</a>" ("Sinan Toprak is the Incorruptible", 2001–2002) and "<a href="Mordkommission%20Istanbul">Mordkommission Istanbul</a>" ("Murder Squad Istanbul", 2008–present) which both star <a href="Erol%20Sander">Erol Sander</a>. In 2005 <a href="Tevfik%20Ba%C5%9Fer">Tevfik Başer</a>'s book ("Time of Wishes") was turned into a primetime TV German movie starring <a href="Erhan%20Emre">Erhan Emre</a>, <a href="Lale%20Yava%C5%9F">Lale Yavaş</a>, <a href="Tim%20Seyfi">Tim Seyfi</a>, and <a href="Hilmi%20S%C3%B6zer">Hilmi Sözer</a>, and won the prestigious <a href="Adolf%20Grimme%20Prize">Adolf Grimme Prize</a>. Another popular Turkish-German TV series was "<a href="Alle%20lieben%20Jimmy">Alle lieben Jimmy</a>" ("Everybody Loves Jimmy", 2006–2007) starring and <a href="G%C3%BClcan%20Kamps">Gülcan Kamps</a>. Due to the success of , it was made into a Turkish series called – making it the first German series to be exported to Turkey.
By 2006 the award-winning German television comedy-drama series "<a href="T%C3%BCrkisch%20f%C3%BCr%20Anf%C3%A4nger">Türkisch für Anfänger</a>" ('Turkish for Beginners', 2006–2009) became one of the most popular shows in Germany. The critically acclaimed series was also shown in more than 70 other countries. Created by <a href="Bora%20Da%C4%9Ftekin">Bora Dağtekin</a>, the plot is based on interethnic-relations between German and Turkish people. <a href="Adnan%20Maral">Adnan Maral</a> plays the role of a widower of two children who marries an ethnic German mother of two children – forming the Öztürk-Schneider family. The comedy consisted of fifty-two episodes and three seasons. By 2012 was made into a feature film; it was the most successful German film of the year with an audience of 2.5 million.
Other notable Turkish-origin actors on German television include <a href="Erdo%C4%9Fan%20Atalay">Erdoğan Atalay</a>, , , , <a href="%C3%96zg%C3%BCr%20%C3%96zata">Özgür Özata</a>, , and .
Whilst Turkish-origin journalists are still underrepresented, several have made successful careers as reporters and TV presenters including and <a href="Nazan%20Eckes">Nazan Eckes</a>.
Many Turkish Germans have also starred in numerous critically acclaimed <a href="Turkish%20television%20drama">Turkish drama series</a>. For example, numerous actors and actresses in "<a href="Muhte%C5%9Fem%20Y%C3%BCzy%C4%B1l">Muhteşem Yüzyıl</a>" were born in Germany, including <a href="Meryem%20Uzerli">Meryem Uzerli</a>, <a href="Nur%20Fettaho%C4%9Flu">Nur Fettahoğlu</a>, <a href="Selma%20Erge%C3%A7">Selma Ergeç</a>, and <a href="Ozan%20G%C3%BCven">Ozan Güven</a>. Other popular Turkish-German performers in Turkey include <a href="Fahriye%20Evcen">Fahriye Evcen</a> who has starred in "<a href="Yaprak%20D%C3%B6k%C3%BCm%C3%BC%20%28TV%20series%29">Yaprak Dökümü</a>" and "<a href="Kurt%20Seyit%20ve%20%C5%9Eura">Kurt Seyit ve Şura</a>".
Comedy.
One of the first comedians of Turkish origin to begin a career as a mainstream comedian is <a href="Django%20As%C3%BCl">Django Asül</a> who began his career in satire in the 1990s. Another very successful comedian is <a href="B%C3%BClent%20Ceylan">Bülent Ceylan</a>, who performed his first solo show "Doner for one" in 2002. By 2011 the broadcasting agency RTL aired Ceylan's own comedy show "The Bulent Ceylan Show". Other notable comedians include , , , , <a href="Kaya%20Yanar">Kaya Yanar</a>, and female comedian .
Literature.
Since the 1960s Turkish people in Germany have produced a range of literature. Their work became widely available from the late 1970s onwards, when Turkish-origin writers began to gain sponsorships by German institutions and major publishing houses. Some of the most notable writers of Turkish origin in Germany include <a href="Akif%20Pirin%C3%A7ci">Akif Pirinçci</a>, <a href="Alev%20Tekinay">Alev Tekinay</a>, <a href="Emine%20Sevgi%20%C3%96zdamar">Emine Sevgi Özdamar</a>, <a href="Feridun%20Zaimo%C4%9Flu">Feridun Zaimoğlu</a>, <a href="Necla%20Kelek">Necla Kelek</a>, <a href="Renan%20Demirkan">Renan Demirkan</a>, and <a href="Zafer%20%C5%9Eenocak">Zafer Şenocak</a>. These writers approach a broad range of historical, social and political issues, such as identity, gender, racism, and language. In particular, German audiences have often been captivated by Oriental depictions of the Turkish community.
Music.
In the mid-twentieth century the Turkish immigrant community in Germany mostly followed the music industry in Turkey, particularly pop music and <a href="Turkish%20folk%20music">Turkish folk music</a>. Hence, the <a href="Turkish%20music">Turkish music</a> industry became very profitable in Germany. By the 1970s, the "<a href="arabesque">arabesque</a>" genre erupted in Turkey and became particularly popular among Turks in Germany. These songs were often played and sang by the Turkish community in Germany in coffee houses and taverns that replicated those in Turkey. These spaces also provided the first stage for semi-professional and professional musicians. Consequently, by the end of the 1960s, some Turks in Germany began to produce their own music, such as who took up themes of the Turkish immigration journey and their working conditions.
By the 1990s the Turkish Germans became more influential in the music industry in both Germany and Turkey. In general, many Turkish Germans were brought up listening to Turkish pop music, which greatly influenced the music they began to produce. They were also influenced by <a href="hip-hop%20music">hip-hop music</a> and <a href="rap%20music">rap music</a>.
Since the 1990s, the Turkish-German music scene has developed creative and successful new styles, such as "Oriental pop and rap" and "R'n'Besk" - a fusion of <a href="Turkish%20music">Turkish</a> <a href="Arabesque%20%28Turkish%20music%29">arabesque</a> songs and <a href="R%26amp%3BB%20music">R&B music</a>. Examples of Oriental-pop and rap emerged in the early 2000s with Bassturk's first single "" ("Side by Side"). The "R'n'Besk"-style gained popularity in Germany with <a href="Muhabbet">Muhabbet</a>'s 2005 single "" ("She lies in my Arms"). By 2007 Muhabbet released the song "" ("Germany"); the lyrics appeal to Germans to finally accept the Turkish immigrants living in the country.
In 2015 several Turkish-German musicians released the song "" ("You are one of us"). The vocalists included <a href="Eko%20Fresh">Eko Fresh</a>, <a href="Elif%20Batman">Elif Batman</a>, <a href="Mehtab%20Guitar">Mehtab Guitar</a>, , and . , <a href="Ercandize">Ercandize</a>, <a href="Serdar%20Bogatekin">Serdar Bogatekin</a>, and <a href="Zafer%20Kurus">Zafer Kurus</a> were also involved in the production. The song was used in a campaign to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the <a href="Ay%20Yildiz">Ay Yildiz</a> telephone network and was extensively broadcast on TV and radio. Thereafter, a competition and group was formed called / ("The voice of the new generation") to find new Turkish-German talent and "" was re-released with different lyrics.
Other Turkish-origin musicians in the German music industry include <a href="Bahar%20K%C4%B1z%C4%B1l">Bahar Kızıl</a> (from the former girl-group <a href="Monrose">Monrose</a>), and winner of Germany's ""<a href="Star%20Search">Star Search</a>"" <a href="Martin%20Kesici">Martin Kesici</a>.
Several Turkish-origin singers born in Germany have also launched their careers in Turkey, such as <a href="Ak%C4%B1n%20Eldes">Akın Eldes</a>, <a href="Aylin%20Asl%C4%B1m">Aylin Aslım</a>, , <a href="%C4%B0smail%20YK">İsmail YK</a>, <a href="Ozan%20Musluo%C4%9Flu">Ozan Musluoğlu</a>, <a href="Pamela%20Spence">Pamela Spence</a>, and <a href="Tarkan%20%28singer%29">Tarkan</a>. The German-born <a href="Turkish%20Cypriot">Turkish Cypriot</a> pianist <a href="R%C3%BCya%20Taner">Rüya Taner</a> has also launched her career in Turkey.
There are also some musicians who perform and produce songs in the English language, such as <a href="Alev%20Lenz">Alev Lenz</a>, <a href="DJ%20Quicksilver">DJ Quicksilver</a>, <a href="DJ%20Sakin">DJ Sakin</a>, and <a href="Mousse%20T.">Mousse T.</a>
Rappers.
Especially in the 1990s, Turkish-German rap groups have sold hundreds of thousands of albums and singles in Turkey, telling their stories of integration and assimilation struggles they experienced due to discrimination they faced during their upbringing in Germany.
Sports.
Football.
 
Men's football.
Many football players of Turkish origin in Germany have been successful in first-division German and Turkish football clubs, as well as other European clubs. However, in regards to playing for national teams, many players of Turkish origin who were born in Germany have chosen to play for the <a href="Turkish%20national%20football%20team">Turkish national football team</a>. Nonetheless, in recent years there has been an increase in the number of players choosing to represent Germany.
The first person of Turkish descent to play for the <a href="Germany%20national%20football%20team">Germany national football team</a> was <a href="Mehmet%20Scholl">Mehmet Scholl</a> in 1993, followed by <a href="Mustafa%20Do%C4%9Fan">Mustafa Doğan</a> in 1999 and <a href="Malik%20Fathi">Malik Fathi</a> in 2006. Since the twenty-first century there has been an increase in German-born individuals of Turkish origin opting to play for Germany, including <a href="Serdar%20Tasci">Serdar Tasci</a> and <a href="Suat%20Serdar">Suat Serdar</a>, <a href="Kerem%20Demirbay">Kerem Demirbay</a>, <a href="Emre%20Can">Emre Can</a>, <a href="%C4%B0lkay%20G%C3%BCndo%C4%9Fan">İlkay Gündoğan</a>, <a href="Mesut%20%C3%96zil">Mesut Özil</a>. Of those, Mesut Özil played the most matches for Germany (92 apps). His photo with Turkish president Recep Tayyip Erdoğan (together with Ilkay Gündogan and Cenk Tosun) just before the World Cup 2018 and his subsequent retirement after World Cup led to a controversy as well as political and 
social discussion. In his retirement statement, Özil also reported about racism experiences after his photo with Erdoğan.
Those who have chosen to retain their Turkish citizenship and who have competed for Turkey include <a href="Cenk%20Tosun">Cenk Tosun</a>, <a href="Ceyhun%20G%C3%BClselam">Ceyhun Gülselam</a>, <a href="G%C3%B6khan%20T%C3%B6re">Gökhan Töre</a>, <a href="Hakan%20Balta">Hakan Balta</a>, <a href="Hakan%20%C3%87alhano%C4%9Flu">Hakan Çalhanoğlu</a>, <a href="Halil%20Alt%C4%B1ntop">Halil Altıntop</a>, <a href="Hamit%20Alt%C4%B1ntop">Hamit Altıntop</a>, <a href="%C4%B0lhan%20Mans%C4%B1z">İlhan Mansız</a>, <a href="Nuri%20%C5%9Eahin">Nuri Şahin</a>, <a href="Og%C3%BCn%20Temizkano%C4%9Flu">Ogün Temizkanoğlu</a>, <a href="Olcay%20%C5%9Eahan">Olcay Şahan</a>, <a href="Mehmet%20Ekici">Mehmet Ekici</a>, <a href="Serhat%20Akin">Serhat Akin</a>, <a href="Tayfun%20Korkut">Tayfun Korkut</a>, <a href="Tayfur%20Havut%C3%A7u">Tayfur Havutçu</a>, <a href="Tunay%20Torun">Tunay Torun</a>, <a href="%C3%9Cmit%20Davala">Ümit Davala</a>, <a href="Umit%20Karan">Umit Karan</a>, <a href="Volkan%20Arslan">Volkan Arslan</a>, <a href="Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1ray%20Ba%C5%9Ft%C3%BCrk">Yıldıray Baştürk</a>, <a href="Yunus%20Mall%C4%B1">Yunus Mallı</a>, <a href="Kaan%20Ayhan">Kaan Ayhan</a>, <a href="Ahmed%20Kutucu">Ahmed Kutucu</a>, <a href="Kenan%20Karaman">Kenan Karaman</a>, <a href="%C3%96mer%20Toprak">Ömer Toprak</a>, <a href="Nazim%20Sangar%C3%A9">Nazim Sangaré</a>, <a href="G%C3%BCven%20Yal%C3%A7%C4%B1n">Güven Yalçın</a>, <a href="Berkay%20%C3%96zcan">Berkay Özcan</a> and <a href="Hasan%20Ali%20Kald%C4%B1r%C4%B1m">Hasan Ali Kaldırım</a>.
Many Turkish Germans have also played for other national football teams; for example, Turkish German football players in the <a href="Azerbaijan%20national%20football%20team">Azerbaijan national football team</a> include <a href="Ufuk%20Budak">Ufuk Budak</a>, <a href="Tu%C4%9Frul%20Erat">Tuğrul Erat</a>, <a href="Ali%20G%C3%B6kdemir">Ali Gökdemir</a>, <a href="Ilter%20Tashkin">Taşkın İlter</a>, <a href="Cihan%20%C3%96zkara">Cihan Özkara</a>, <a href="U%C4%9Fur%20Pamuk">Uğur Pamuk</a>, <a href="Fatih%20%C5%9Eanl%C4%B1">Fatih Şanlı</a>, and .
Several Turkish-German professional football players have also continued their careers as football managers such as <a href="Kenan%20Kocak">Kenan Kocak</a>, , <a href="Tayfun%20Korkut">Tayfun Korkut</a> and . In addition, there are also several Turkish-German referees, including <a href="Deniz%20Aytekin">Deniz Aytekin</a>.
Women's football.
In regards to women's football, several players have chosen to play for the <a href="Turkey%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Turkish women's national football team</a>, including <a href="Aylin%20Yaren">Aylin Yaren</a>, <a href="Aycan%20Yana%C3%A7">Aycan Yanaç</a>, <a href="Melike%20Pekel">Melike Pekel</a>, <a href="Dilan%20A%C4%9Fg%C3%BCl">Dilan Ağgül</a>, <a href="Selin%20Di%C5%9Fli">Selin Dişli</a>, <a href="Arzu%20Karabulut">Arzu Karabulut</a>, <a href="Ecem%20Cumert">Ecem Cumert</a>, <a href="Fatma%20Kara">Fatma Kara</a>, <a href="Fatma%20I%C5%9F%C4%B1k">Fatma Işık</a>, <a href="Ebru%20Uzung%C3%BCney">Ebru Uzungüney</a> and <a href="Feride%20Bak%C4%B1r">Feride Bakır</a>.
There are also players who plays for the <a href="Germany%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">German women's football national football team</a>, including <a href="Sara%20Doorsoun">Sara Doorsoun</a> and <a href="Hasret%20Kayik%C3%A7i">Hasret Kayıkçı</a>.
Turkish-German football clubs.
The Turkish community in Germany has also been active in establishing their own football clubs such as <a href="Berlin%20T%C3%BCrkspor%201965">Berlin Türkspor 1965</a> (established in 1965) and <a href="T%C3%BCrkiyemspor%20Berlin">Türkiyemspor Berlin</a> (established in 1978). Türkiyemspor Berlin were the Champions in the <a href="Berlin-Liga">Berlin-Liga</a> in the year 2000. They were the winners of the <a href="Berliner%20Landespokal">Berliner Landespokal</a> in 1988, 1990, and 1991.
Politics.
German politics.
The Turks in Germany began to be active in politics by establishing associations and federations in the 1960s and 1970s – though these were mainly based on Turkish politics rather than German politics. The first significant step towards active German politics occurred in 1987 when <a href="Sevim%20%C3%87elebi-Gottschlich">Sevim Çelebi</a> became the first person of Turkish origin to be elected as an MP in the West Berlin Parliament.
With the reunification of <a href="East%20Germany">East Germany</a> and <a href="West%20Germany">West Germany</a>, unemployment in the country had increased and some political parties, particularly the <a href="Christian%20Democratic%20Union%20of%20Germany">Christian Democratic Union</a> (CDU), used anti-immigration discourses as a political tool in their campaigns. To counter this, many people of Turkish origin became more politically active and began to work in local elections and in the young branches of the <a href="Social%20Democratic%20Party%20of%20Germany">Social Democratic Party</a> (SPD) and the <a href="Alliance%20%2790/The%20Greens">Green Party</a>. Several associations were founded by almost all German parties to organise meetings for Turkish voters. This played an important gateway for those who aspired to become politicians.
Federal Parliament.
In <a href="1994%20German%20federal%20election">1994</a> from the SPD and <a href="Cem%20%C3%96zdemir">Cem Özdemir</a> from the <a href="Alliance%20%2790/The%20Greens">Green Party</a> became MPs in the Federal Parliament. They were both re-elected in the 1998 elections and were joined by <a href="Ekin%20Delig%C3%B6z">Ekin Deligöz</a> from the Green party. Deligöz and Özdemir were both re-elected as MPs for the Greens and <a href="Lale%20Akg%C3%BCn">Lale Akgün</a> was elected as an MP for the SPD in the <a href="2002%20German%20federal%20election">2002 elections</a>. Thereafter, Deligöz and Akgün were successful in being re-elected in the <a href="2005%20German%20federal%20election">2005 elections</a>; the two female politicians were joined by <a href="Hakk%C4%B1%20Keskin">Hakkı Keskin</a> who was elected as an MP for the <a href="The%20Left%20%28Germany%29">Left Party</a>.
By the end of the first decade of the twenty-first century, the number of German MPs of Turkish origin remained similar to the previous elections. In the <a href="2009%20German%20federal%20election">2009 elections</a> <a href="Ekin%20Delig%C3%B6z">Ekin Deligöz</a> and <a href="Mehmet%20K%C4%B1l%C4%B1%C3%A7">Mehmet Kılıç</a> were elected for the Greens, <a href="Aydan%20%C3%96zo%C4%9Fuz">Aydan Özoğuz</a> for the SPD, and for the <a href="Free%20Democratic%20Party%20%28Germany%29">FDP</a>. Nonetheless, several Turkish-origin politicians were successful in becoming ministers and co-chairs of political parties. For example, in 2008 <a href="Cem%20%C3%96zdemir">Cem Özdemir</a> became the co-chair of the <a href="Alliance%20%2790/The%20Greens">Green Party</a>. In 2010 <a href="Ayg%C3%BCl%20%C3%96zkan">Aygül Özkan</a> was appointed as the Women, Family, Health and Integration Minister, making her the first ever minister of Turkish origin or the Muslim faith. In the same year, <a href="Aydan%20%C3%96zo%C4%9Fuz">Aydan Özoğuz</a> was elected as deputy chairperson of the <a href="Social%20Democratic%20Party%20of%20Germany">SPD</a> party. By 2011, from the SPD was appointed as Integration Minister in the Baden-Württemberg State.
Since the <a href="2013%20German%20federal%20election">2013 German elections</a>, Turkish-origin MPs have been elected into Federal Parliament from four different parties. <a href="Cemile%20Giousouf">Cemile Giousouf</a>, whose parents immigrated from <a href="Greece">Greece</a>, became the first person of <a href="Turks%20of%20Western%20Thrace">Western Thracian Turkish-origin</a> to become an MP. Giousouf was the first Turkish-origin MP and first Muslim to be elected from the CDU party. Five MPs of Turkish-origin were elected from the SPD party including <a href="Aydan%20%C3%96zo%C4%9Fuz">Aydan Özoğuz</a>, <a href="Cansel%20Kiziltepe">Cansel Kiziltepe</a>, <a href="G%C3%BClistan%20Y%C3%BCksel">Gülistan Yüksel</a>, <a href="Metin%20Hakverdi">Metin Hakverdi</a> and <a href="Mahmut%20%C3%96zdemir">Mahmut Özdemir</a>. Özdemir, at the time of his election, became the youngest MP in the German Parliament. For the Green Party, <a href="Cem%20%C3%96zdemir">Cem Özdemir</a>, <a href="Ekin%20Delig%C3%B6z">Ekin Deligöz</a> and <a href="%C3%96zcan%20Mutlu">Özcan Mutlu</a> were elected as MPs, and for the <a href="The%20Left%20%28Germany%29">Left Party</a>.
European Parliament.
In 1989 from the <a href="Social%20Democratic%20Party%20of%20Germany">SPD</a> party was the first person of Turkish-origin to be a member of the <a href="European%20Parliament">European Parliament</a> for Germany. By 2004 <a href="Cem%20%C3%96zdemir">Cem Özdemir</a> and <a href="Vural%20%C3%96ger">Vural Öger</a> also became members of the European Parliament. Since then, <a href="Ismail%20Ertug">Ismail Ertug</a> was elected as a <a href="Member%20of%20the%20European%20Parliament">Member of the European Parliament</a> in 2009 and was re-elected in 2014.
Turkish politics.
Some Turks born or raised in Germany have entered Turkish politics. For example, <a href="Siegen">Siegen</a>-born, <a href="Justice%20and%20Development%20Party%20%28Turkey%29">Justice and Development Party</a> (AKP) affiliated <a href="Akif%20%C3%87a%C4%9Fatay%20K%C4%B1l%C4%B1%C3%A7">Akif Çağatay Kılıç</a> has been the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Youth%20and%20Sports%20%28Turkey%29">Minister of Youth and Sports</a> of <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a> since 2013.
Germany is effectively Turkey's 4th largest electoral district. Around a third of this constituency vote in Turkish elections (570,000 in the 2015 parliamentary elections), and the share of <a href="Conservatism">conservative</a> votes for the <a href="Justice%20and%20Development%20Party%20%28Turkey%29">Justice and Development Party</a> (AKP) and <a href="Recep%20Tayyip%20Erdo%C4%9Fan">Recep Tayyip Erdoğan</a> is even higher than in Turkey itself. Following the <a href="2016%20Turkish%20coup%20d%27%C3%A9tat%20attempt">2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt</a>, huge pro-<a href="Erdogan">Erdogan</a> demonstrations were held by Turkish citizens in German cities. "<a href="The%20Economist">The Economist</a>" suggested that this would make it difficult for Germany politicians to criticize Erdogan's policies and tactics. However, equally huge demonstrations by Turkish Kurds were also held in Germany some weeks later against Erdogan's <a href="2016%20Turkish%20purges">2016 Turkish purges</a> and against the detention the HDP party co-chairpersons <a href="Selahattin%20Demirta%C5%9F">Selahattin Demirtaş</a> and <a href="Figen%20Y%C3%BCksekda%C4%9F">Figen Yüksekdağ</a> in Turkey.
